The result is then added to the sum of the age-specific enrolment rates. The expected number of years does not necessarily coincide with the expected number of grades of education completed because of repetition.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for school life expectancy. Tertiary.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for school life expectancy. Tertiary is the ratio of female school life expectancy (tertiary) to the male school life expectancy (tertiary). It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

wb:indicator.wb:name: School life expectancy (years). Tertiary. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: School life expectancy (years). Tertiary. Male is the total number of years of schooling which a child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, assuming that the probability of his or her being enrolled in school at any particular age is equal to the current enrollment ratio for that age. For a child of a certain age a, the school life expectancy is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the levels of education specified. The part of the enrolment that is not distributed by age is divided by the school-age population for the level of education they are enrolled in, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education. The result is then added to the sum of the age-specific enrolment rates. The expected number of years does not necessarily coincide with the expected number of grades of education completed because of repetition.

wb:indicator.wb:name: School life expectancy net of repetition (years). Primary to lower secondary. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: School life expectancy net of repetition (years). Primary to lower secondary. Female is the number of years of schooling that a female child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, excluding years spent repeating grades. The indicator reflects the overall level of development of an education system in terms of the average number of years of schooling without repetition that can be offered to the school-age population, including those who never enter school. It is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the given level of education, plus the number of pupils of unknown age in the given level of education divided by the school-age population for that level of education, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education, minus the number of repeaters in a given level of education divided by the school-age population for that level, multiplied by the duration of that level of education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for school life expectancy net of repetition. Primary to lower secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for school life expectancy net of repetition. Primary to lower secondary is the ratio of female to male vales for the indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

wb:indicator.wb:name: School life expectancy net of repetition (years). Primary to lower secondary. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: School life expectancy net of repetition (years). Primary to lower secondary. Male is the number of years of schooling that a male child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, excluding years spent repeating grades. The indicator reflects the overall level of development of an education system in terms of the average number of years of schooling without repetition that can be offered to the school-age population, including those who never enter school. It is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the given level of education, plus the number of pupils of unknown age in the given level of education divided by the school-age population for that level of education, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education, minus the number of repeaters in a given level of education divided by the school-age population for that level, multiplied by the duration of that level of education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: School life expectancy net of repetition (years). Primary to lower secondary. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: School life expectancy net of repetition (years). Primary to lower secondary. Total is the number of years of schooling that a child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, excluding years spent repeating grades. The indicator reflects the overall level of development of an education system in terms of the average number of years of schooling without repetition that can be offered to the school-age population, including those who never enter school. It is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the given level of education, plus the number of pupils of unknown age in the given level of education divided by the school-age population for that level of education, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education, minus the number of repeaters in a given level of education divided by the school-age population for that level, multiplied by the duration of that level of education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Survival rate to grade 4. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to grade 4. Total is the share of children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 4. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Survival rate to grade 4. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to grade 4. Female is the share of female children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 4. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for survival rate to grade 4
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for survival rate to grade 4 is the ratio of female survival rate to grade 4 to the male survival rate to grade 4. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Survival rate to grade 4. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to grade 4. Male is the share of male children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 4. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for survival rate to grade 5
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for survival rate to grade 5 is the ratio of female survival rate to grade 5 to the male survival rate to grade 5. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for survival rate to last grade of primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for survival rate to the last grade of primary is the ratio of female survival rate to grade the last grade of primary to the male survival rate to grade the last grade of primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Female is the share of female children enrolled in the first grade of secondary school who eventually reach the last grade of secondary school, regardless of repetition. To calculate this indicator, divide the total number of female pupils in the last grade of secondary education by the number of female pupils who originally enrolled in the first grade of secondary education, and multiply the result by 100. The survival rate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Male is the share of male children enrolled in the first grade of secondary school who eventually reach the last grade of secondary school, regardless of repetition. To calculate this indicator, divide the total number of male pupils in the last grade of secondary education by the number of male pupils who originally enrolled in the first grade of secondary education, and multiply the result by 100. The survival rate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Total is the share of children enrolled in the first grade of secondary school who eventually reach the last grade of secondary school, regardless of repetition. To calculate this indicator, divide the total number of pupils in the last grade of secondary education by the number of pupils who originally enrolled in the first grade of secondary education, and multiply the result by 100. The survival rate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes) is the ratio of female to male vales for the indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teaching staff in lower secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in lower secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in public and private lower secondary education institutions (ISCED 2). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teaching staff in lower secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in lower secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in public and private lower secondary education institutions (ISCED 2). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in lower secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. General programmes. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teaching staff in lower secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. General programmes. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in lower secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. General programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in general programmes in public and private lower secondary education institutions (ISCED 2). This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of students in tertiary education per 100,000 inhabitants. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of students in tertiary education per 100,000 inhabitants. Total is the number of students enrolled in tertiary education in a given academic year per 100,000 inhabitants. It is calculated by dividing the total number of students enrolled in tertiary education in a given academic year by the country’s population and multiplying the result by 100,000.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of students in tertiary education per 100,000 inhabitants. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of students in tertiary education per 100,000 inhabitants. Female is the number of female students enrolled in tertiary education in a given academic year per 100,000 inhabitants. It is calculated by dividing the total number of female students enrolled in tertiary education in a given academic year by the country’s population and multiplying the result by 100,000.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of students in tertiary education per 100,000 inhabitants. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of students in tertiary education per 100,000 inhabitants. Male is the number of male students enrolled in tertiary education in a given academic year per 100,000 inhabitants. It is calculated by dividing the total number of male students enrolled in tertiary education in a given academic year by the country’s population and multiplying the result by 100,000.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Distribution of students (%). ISCED Level 5A
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Distribution of students (%). Tertiary ISCED Level 5A is the enrolment in tertiary education at ISCED level 5A as a percentage of total enrolment in tertiary education. ISCED level 5A programmes are tertiary programmes that are largely theoretically based and are intended to provide sufficient qualifications for gaining entry into advanced research programmes and professions with high skills requirements.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Distribution of students (%). ISCED Level 5B
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Distribution of students (%). Tertiary ISCED Level 5B is the enrolment in tertiary education at ISCED level 5B as a percentage of total enrolment in tertiary education. The content of tertiary ISCED level 5B programmes is practically oriented/occupationally specific and is mainly designed for participants to acquire the practical skills needed for employment in a particular occupation or trade or class of occupations or trades - the successful completion of which usually provides the participants with a labor-market relevant qualification.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Distribution of students (%). ISCED Level 6
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Distribution of students (%). Tertiary ISCED Level 6 is the enrolment in tertiary education at ISCED level 6 as a percentage of total enrolment in tertiary education. ISCED Level 6 is reserved for tertiary programmes which lead to the award of an advanced research qualification. The programmes are therefore devoted to advanced study and original research and are not based on coursework only. It typically requires the submission of a thesis or dissertation of publishable quality which is the product of original research and represents a significant contribution to knowledge. It prepares graduates for faculty posts in institutions offering ISCED 5A programmes, as well as research posts in government, industry, etc.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Entrance age of pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Entrance age of pre-primary is the age at which students would enter pre-primary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Entrance age of 3A upper secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Entrance age of 3A upper secondary is the age at which students would enter ISCED 3A upper secondary education, assuming they had started at the official entrance age for the lowest level of education, had studied full-time throughout and had progressed through the system without repeating or skipping a grade.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Entrance age of 4A post-secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Entrance age of 4A post-secondary is the age at which students would enter ISCED 4A post-secondary education, assuming they had started at the official entrance age for the lowest level of education, had studied full-time throughout and had progressed through the system without repeating or skipping a grade.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Duration of pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Duration of pre-primary is the number of grades (years) in pre-primary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Duration of 4A post-secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Duration of 4A post-secondary is the number of grades (years) in 4A post-secondary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for transition rate, primary to secondary, general programmes
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for transition rate, primary to secondary, general programmes is the ratio of the female transition rate from primary to secondary (general programmes) to the male value for the same indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Effective transition rate from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes (%). Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Effective transition rate from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes (%). Total shows the real transition from primary to secondary regardless of repetition. This indicator better reflects situations in which pupils repeat the last grade of primary but eventually make the transition to secondary. It is defined for a given year as the number of new entrants to the first grade of secondary in the following year expressed as a percentage of the students enrolled in the last grade of primary education in the given year who do not repeat that grade the following year.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Effective transition rate from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes (%). Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Effective transition rate from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes (%). Female shows the real transition from primary to secondary regardless of repetition. This indicator better reflects situations in which pupils repeat the last grade of primary but eventually make the transition to secondary. It is defined for a given year as the number of new female entrants to the first grade of secondary in the following year expressed as a percentage of the female students enrolled in the last grade of primary education in the given year who do not repeat that grade the following year.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for effective transition rate. Primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for effective transition rate. Primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes is the ratio of the female effective transition rate to the male value for the same indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Effective transition rate from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes (%). Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Effective transition rate from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes (%). Male shows the real transition from primary to secondary regardless of repetition. This indicator better reflects situations in which pupils repeat the last grade of primary but eventually make the transition to secondary. It is defined for a given year as the number of new male entrants to the first grade of secondary in the following year expressed as a percentage of the male students enrolled in the last grade of primary education in the given year who do not repeat that grade the following year.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage of trained teachers. Pre-primary. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Pre-primary. Total is the number of teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the pre-primary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers at the pre-primary level.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage of trained teachers. Pre-primary. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Pre-primary. Female is the number of female teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the pre-primary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of female teachers at the pre-primary level.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for % of trained teachers. Pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for % of trained teachers. Pre-primary is the ratio of the female percentage of trained teachers for pre-primary to the male percentage of trained teachers for pre-primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of men and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of women.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage of trained teachers. Pre-primary. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Pre-primary. Male is the number of male teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the pre-primary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of male teachers at the pre-primary level.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for % of trained teachers. Primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for % of trained teachers. Primary is the ratio of the female percentage of trained teachers for primary to the male percentage of trained teachers for primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of men and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of women.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Lower secondary. wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage of trained teachers. Lower secondary. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Lower secondary. Female is the number of female teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the lower secondary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of female teachers at the lower secondary level.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Lower secondary. wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for % of trained teachers. Secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for % of trained teachers. Secondary is the ratio of the female percentage of trained teachers for secondary to the male percentage of trained teachers for secondary. wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage of trained teachers. Upper secondary. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Upper secondary. Total is the number of teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the upper secondary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers at the upper secondary level.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage of trained teachers. Upper secondary. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Upper secondary. Female is the number of female teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the upper secondary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of female teachers at the upper secondary level.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gender parity index for % of trained teachers. Upper secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for % of trained teachers. Upper secondary is the ratio of the female percentage of trained teachers for upper secondary to the male percentage of trained teachers for upper secondary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of men and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of women.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage of trained teachers. Upper secondary. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Upper secondary. Male is the number of male teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the upper secondary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of male teachers at the upper secondary level.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Under-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Under-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Total is the percentage of the primary school age population (ISCED 1) that is under the official primary school age.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Under-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Under-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Female is the percentage of the female primary school age population (ISCED 1) that is under the official primary school age.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Under-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Under-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Male is the percentage of the male primary school age population (ISCED 1) that is under the official primary school age.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Pre-primary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to pre-primary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Lower secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Lower secondary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to lower secondary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Upper secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Upper secondary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to upper secondary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Post secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Post secondary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to post-secondary education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education not allocated by level
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education not allocated by level is the share of public current education expenditure that is not devoted to a specified level of education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Pre-primary is the expenditure coming from public, private and international sources spent on pre-primary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. Pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. Pre-primary is the expenditure coming from public sources spent on pre-primary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. Pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. Pre-primary is the expenditure coming from private sources spent on pre-primary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Primary is the expenditure coming from public, private and international sources spent on primary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. Primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. Primary is the expenditure coming from public sources spent on primary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. Primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. Primary is the expenditure coming from private sources spent on primary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary is the expenditure coming from public, private and international sources spent on secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. Secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. Secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary is the expenditure coming from private sources spent on secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Tertiary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Tertiary is the expenditure coming from public, private and international sources spent on tertiary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. Tertiary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. Tertiary is the expenditure coming from private sources spent on tertiary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. All levels
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. All levels is the expenditure coming from public, private and international sources spent on education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. All levels
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. All levels is the expenditure coming from public sources spent education expressed as a % of GDP. This indicator excludes public transfers and payments to private entities.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. International sources. All levels
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. International sources. All levels is the expenditure coming from international sources spent on education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. All levels
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Private sources. All levels is the expenditure coming from private sources spent on education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Current expenditure on education as % of GNI
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Current expenditure on education as % of GNI is the total public current education expenditure expressed as a percentage of the Gross National Income (GNI) in a given financial year. GNI is also referred to as Gross National Product (GNP).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public current expenditure on education as % of total current government expenditure
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public current expenditure on education as % of total current government expenditure is the share of total government current expenditures for the education sector.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in primary education. All personnel salaries
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in primary education. All personnel salaries is the percentage of public current expenditures on primary education devoted to salaries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in primary education. Teachers salaries
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in primary education. Teachers salaries is the percentage of public current expenditures on primary education devoted to teachers salaries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in secondary education. All personnel salaries
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in secondary education. All personnel salaries is the percentage of public current expenditures on secondary education devoted to salaries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in secondary education. Teacher salaries
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in secondary education. Teacher salaries is the percentage of public current expenditures on secondary education devoted to teachers salaries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure in pre-primary as % of total educational expenditure
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure in pre-primary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for pre-primary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure in lower secondary as % of total educational expenditure
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure in lower secondary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for lower secondary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure in upper secondary as % of total educational expenditure
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure in upper secondary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for upper secondary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure in post secondary as % of total educational expenditure
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure in post secondary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for post secondary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure not allocated by level as % of total educational expenditure
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure not allocated by level as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure that is not allocated by educational level. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure on capital as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure on capital as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4. is spending on education capital expressed as a percentage of the total expenditure for primary, lower/upper secondary, and post-secondary/non-tertiary education (ISCED 1,2,3, and 4). Public subsidies to the private sector and administrative costs should be excluded. This in indicator is also referred to as "Educational expenditure by nature of spending as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4. Capital."

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure on total current expenditures as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure on total current expenditures as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4. is spending on total current education expenditures expressed as a percentage of the total expenditure for primary, lower/upper secondary, and post-secondary/non-tertiary education (ISCED 1,2,3, and 4). Salaries and other current expenditures add up to the total current expenditure. Public subsidies to the private sector and administrative costs should be excluded. This in indicator is also referred to as "Educational expenditure by nature of spending as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4. Total Current Expenditures."

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure on other current expenditures as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure on other current expenditures as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4. is spending on other current education expenditures (excluding salaries) expressed as a percentage of the total expenditure for primary, lower/upper secondary, and post-secondary/non-tertiary education (ISCED 1,2,3, and 4). Salaries and other current expenditures add up to the total current expenditure. Public subsidies to the private sector and administrative costs should be excluded. This in indicator is also referred to as "Educational expenditure by nature of spending as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4. Other Current Expenditures."

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure on salaries as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure on salaries as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4. is spending on education salaries expressed as a percentage of the total expenditure for primary, lower/upper secondary, and post-secondary/non-tertiary education (ISCED 1,2,3, and 4). Salaries and other current add up to the total current expenditure. Public subsidies to the private sector and administrative costs should be excluded. This in indicator is also referred to as "Educational expenditure by nature of spending as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. ISCED 1,2,3,4. Salaries."

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure on capital as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure on capital as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary. is spending on education capital expressed as a percentage of the total expenditure for tertiary education (ISCED 5 & 6). Public subsidies to the private sector and administrative costs should be excluded. This in indicator is also referred to as "Educational expenditure by nature of spending as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary. Capital."

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure on total current expenditures as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure for total current expenditures as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary. is total current education spending expressed as a percentage of the total expenditure for tertiary education (ISCED 5 & 6). Salaries and other current add up to the total current expenditure. Public subsidies to the private sector and administrative costs should be excluded. This in indicator is also referred to as "Educational expenditure by nature of spending as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary. Total Current Expenditures."

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure on other current expenditures as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure on other current expenditures as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary. is other current education spending (excluding salaries) expressed as a percentage of the total expenditure for tertiary education (ISCED 5 & 6). Salaries and other current add up to the total current expenditure. Public subsidies to the private sector and administrative costs should be excluded. This in indicator is also referred to as "Educational expenditure by nature of spending as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary. Other Current Expenditures."

wb:indicator.wb:name: Educational expenditure on salaries as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure on salaries as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary. is spending on education salaries expressed as a percentage of the total expenditure for tertiary education (ISCED 5 & 6). Salaries and other current add up to the total current expenditure. Public subsidies to the private sector and administrative costs should be excluded. This in indicator is also referred to as "Educational expenditure by nature of spending as a % of total educational expenditure on public institutions. Tertiary. Salaries."

wb:indicator.wb:name: Human development index (HDI)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Human Development Index (HDI) is a summary measure of human development. It measures the average achievements in a country in three basic dimensions of human development: a long and healthy life, access to knowledge and a decent standard of living. The HDI is the geometric mean of normalized indices measuring achievements in each dimension. The HDI is the geometric mean of the three dimension indices and embodies imperfect substitutability across all HDI dimensions. It thus addresses one of the most serious criticisms of the linear aggregation formula, which allowed for perfect substitution across dimensions. Some substitutability is inherent in the definition of any index that increases with the values of its components. Data sources: Life expectancy at birth: UNDESA; Mean years of schooling: Barro and Lee; Expected years of schooling: UNESCO Institute for Statistics; Gross national income (GNI) per capita: World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Combined polity score
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The Combined Polity score is computed by subtracting the AUTOCRACY score (UPP.INS.AUTO.XQ) from the DEMOCRACY score (UPP.INS.DEMO.XQ); the resulting unified polity scale ranges from +10 (strongly democratic) to -10 (strongly autocratic). Note: The POLITY score was added to the Polity IV data series in recognition of its common usage by users in quantitative research and in the overriding interest of maintaining uniformity among users in this application. The simple combination of the original DEMOC and AUTOC index values in a unitary POLITY scale, in many ways, runs contrary to the original theory stated by Eckstein and Gurr in Patterns of Authority Polity IV Project: Dataset Users’ Manual 17 (1975) and, so, should be treated and interpreted with due caution. Its primary utility is in investigative research which should be augmented by more detailed analysis. The original theory posits that autocratic and democratic authority are distinct patterns of authority, elements of which may co-exist in any particular regime context. The inclusion of this variable in the data series should not be seen as an acceptance of the counter-proposal that autocracy and democracy are alternatives or opposites in a unified authority spectrum, even though elements of this perspective may be implied in the original theory. The POLITY variable provides a convenient avenue for examining general regime effects in analyses but researchers should note that the middle of the implied POLITY “spectrum” is somewhat muddled in terms of the original theory, masking various combinations of DEMOC and AUTOC scores with the same POLITY score. Investigations involving hypotheses of varying effects of democracy and/or autocracy should employ the original Polity scheme and test DEMOC and AUTOC separately.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Institutionalized autocracy
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Democracy is conceived as three essential, interdependent elements. One is the presence of institutions and procedures through which citizens can express effective preferences about alternative policies and leaders. Second is the existence of institutionalized constraints on the exercise of power by the executive. Third is the guarantee of civil liberties to all citizens in their daily lives and in acts of political participation. Other aspects of plural democracy, such as the rule of law, systems of checks and balances, freedom of the press, and so on are means to, or specific manifestations of, these general principles. We do not include coded data on civil liberties.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Institutionalized democracy
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Democracy is conceived as three essential, interdependent elements. One is the presence of institutions and procedures through which citizens can express effective preferences about alternative policies and leaders. Second is the existence of institutionalized constraints on the exercise of power by the executive. Third is the guarantee of civil liberties to all citizens in their daily lives and in acts of political participation. Other aspects of plural democracy, such as the rule of law, systems of checks and balances, freedom of the press, and so on are means to, or specific manifestations of, these general principles. We do not include coded data on civil liberties.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revised Combined Polity Score
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Revised Combined Polity Score is a modified version of the POLITY variable added in order to facilitate the use of the POLITY regime measure in time-series analyses.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Authoritarian regime"" in Western political discourse is a pejorative term for some very diverse kinds of political systems whose common properties are a lack of regularized political competition and concern for political freedoms. The term Autocracy is used and defined operationally in terms of the presence of a distinctive set of political characteristics. In mature form, autocracies sharply restrict or suppress competitive political participation. Their chief executives are chosen in a regularized process of selection within the political elite, and once in office they exercise power with few institutional constraints. Most modern autocracies also exercise a high degree of directiveness over social and economic activity, but we regard this as a function of political ideology and choice, not a defining property of autocracy. Social democracies also exercise relatively high degrees of directiveness. The Polity data producers prefer to leave open for empirical investigation the question of how Autocracy, Democracy, and directiveness (performance) have covaried over time.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Urea, E. Europe, bulk, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Urea, (Black Sea), bulk, spot, f.o.b. Black Sea (primarily Yuzhnyy) beginning July 1991; for 1985-91 (June) f.o.b. Eastern Europe
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Fertilizer Week; Fertilizer International; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Voice and Accountability: Estimate
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Voice and Accountability captures perceptions of the extent to which a country's citizens are able to participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Voice and Accountability: Number of Sources
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Voice and Accountability captures perceptions of the extent to which a country's citizens are able to participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Voice and Accountability: Percentile Rank
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Voice and Accountability captures perceptions of the extent to which a country's citizens are able to participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Voice and Accountability: Standard Error
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Voice and Accountability captures perceptions of the extent to which a country's citizens are able to participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Battle-related deaths (number of people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Battle-related deaths are deaths in battle-related conflicts between warring parties in the conflict dyad (two conflict units that are parties to a conflict). Typically, battle-related deaths occur in warfare involving the armed forces of the warring parties. This includes traditional battlefield fighting, guerrilla activities, and all kinds of bombardments of military units, cities, and villages, etc. The targets are usually the military itself and its installations or state institutions and state representatives, but there is often substantial collateral damage in the form of civilians being killed in crossfire, in indiscriminate bombings, etc. All deaths--military as well as civilian--incurred in such situations, are counted as battle-related deaths.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Internally displaced persons (number, high estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Internally displaced persons are people or groups of people who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence, in particular as a result of armed conflict, or to avoid the effects of armed conflict, situations of generalized violence, violations of human rights, or natural or human-made disasters and who have not crossed an international border.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Internally displaced persons (number, low estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Internally displaced persons are people or groups of people who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence, in particular as a result of armed conflict, or to avoid the effects of armed conflict, situations of generalized violence, violations of human rights, or natural or human-made disasters and who have not crossed an international border.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Intentional homicides (per 100,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Intentional homicides are estimates of unlawful homicides purposely inflicted as a result of domestic disputes, interpersonal violence, violent conflicts over land resources, intergang violence over turf or control, and predatory violence and killing by armed groups. Intentional homicide does not include all intentional killing; the difference is usually in the organization of the killing. Individuals or small groups usually commit homicide, whereas killing in armed conflict is usually committed by fairly cohesive groups of up to several hundred members and is thus usually excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UN Office on Drugs and Crime's International Homicide Statistics database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Presence of peace keepers (number of troops, police, and military observers in mandate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Presence of peacebuilders and peacekeepers are active in peacebuilding and peacekeeping. Peacebuilding reduces the risk of lapsing or relapsing into conflict by strengthening national capacities at all levels of for conflict management, and to lay the foundation for sustainable peace and development. Peacekeepers provide essential security to preserve the peace, however fragile, where fighting has been halted, and to assist in implementing agreements achieved by the peacemakers. Peacekeepers deploy to war-torn regions where no one else is willing or able to go and prevent conflict from returning or escalating. Peacekeepers include police, troops, and military observers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UN Department of Peacekeeping Operations, http://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wheat, Canada, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wheat (Canada), no. 1, Western Red Spring (CWRS), in store, St. Lawrence, export price
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Canadian Grain Commission; Thomson Reuters Datastream; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wheat, US, HRW, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wheat (US), no. 1, hard red winter, ordinary protein, export price delivered at the US Gulf port for prompt or 30 days shipment

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wheat, US, SRW, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wheat (US), no. 2, soft red winter, export price delivered at the US Gulf port for prompt or 30 days shipment

wb:indicator.wb:name: Woodpulp, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Woodpulp (Sweden), softwood, sulphate, bleached, air-dry weight, c.i.f. North Sea ports
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Statistisches Bundesamt, Germany; Allman Manadsstatistik, Sweden; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Male-female gap in the percent of population (15+) with an account at a formal financial institution
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This indicator measures the difference between the percentage of males and the percentage of females of ages 15 and above who have an account (self or together with someone else) at a formal financial institutions, such as bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperative, microfinance institution), or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data are obtained from Demirguc-Kunt and Klapper (2012), Measuring Financial Inclusion: The Global Findex Database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution (% age 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperatives, microfinance institutions) or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% age 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, rural (% age 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperatives, microfinance institutions) or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% living in an urban area, age 15+ )

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, urban (% age 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperatives, microfinance institutions) or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% living in a rural area, age 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, male (% age 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Account at a formal financial institution, male (% age 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, female (% age 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Account at a formal financial institution, female (% age 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, young adults (% ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperatives, microfinance institutions) or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% ages 15-24)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, older adults (% age 25+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperatives, microfinance institutions) or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% age 25+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, primary education or less (% age 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperatives, microfinance institutions) or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% with a primary education or less, age 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, secondary education or more (% age 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperatives, microfinance institutions) or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% with a secondary education or more, age 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, income, bottom 40% (% age 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperatives, microfinance institutions) or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% in the first (lowest) and second income quintiles (0-40th percentile), age 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account at a formal financial institution, income quintiles III, IV, and V (highest) (% age 15+)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Global Findex ( Global Financial Inclusion database)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults with an account (self or together with someone else) at a bank, credit union, another financial institution (e.g., cooperatives, microfinance institutions) or the post office (if applicable) including respondents who reported having a debit card (% in the third, fourth, and fifth (highest) income quintiles (41st-100th percentile), age 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Account used for business purposes (% age 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. Secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. Secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary is the expenditure coming from public sources spent on secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. Tertiary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. Public sources. Tertiary is the expenditure coming from public sources spent on tertiary education expressed as a % of GDP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export Market Growth Index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The export market growth index measures the trade-weighted external demand for a country's merchandise goods exports based on the import demand in its export markets.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates and IMF Directions of Trade Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Zinc, cents/kg, current$

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Platts Metals Week, Engineering and Mining Journal; Thomson Reuters Datastream; World Bank.
